0: The fourth Star Trek TV series, Voyager, premieres on UPN in the United States

1901.4: "Speak softly and carry a big stick"

1901.5: Theodore Roosevelt president for the first time

1902.5: The first teddy bear is produced

1903.1: First Tour de France bicycle race

1903.3: The first box of Crayola crayons

1904.3: The Pi Kappa Phi fraternity is founded

1905.4: French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State

1906.2: Mahatma Gandhi coins the term Satyagraha

1908.0: A long-distance radio message is sent from the Eiffel Tower for the first time

1908.1: French aviator Léon Delagrange pilots the first passenger flight with Henri Farman on board

1908.2: The 1908 Summer Olympics are held in London

1909.0: Colombia recognizes the independence of Panama

1909.1: Einar Dessau uses a shortwave radio transmitter, becoming the first radio broadcaster

1910.0: The first aviation meeting to be held in the United States, the 1910 Los Angeles

1910.1: In France Raymonde de Laroche is awarded pilot's license #36 by the Federation Aeronautique Internationale, becoming the first woman authorized to fly an airplane

1910.2: The first filmed version of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein comes out. Considered to be the first horror movie, it stars actor

1910.3: In Brazil, Sport Club Corinthians Paulista, the first Fifa World Club Championship, is founded

1911.0: Eugene B. Ely lands on the deck of the USS Pennsylvania stationed in San Francisco harbor, marking the first time an aircraft lands on a ship

1911.1: International Women's Day is celebrated for the first time in history

1911.2: World's first combat aerial bombing mission takes place in Libya during the Italo-Turkish War. Second Lieutenant Giulio Gavotti of Italy drops several small bombs

1912.0: New Mexico becomes the 47th state of the United States

1912.1: Albert Berry is reported to have made the first parachute jump from a flying airplane

1912.2: Alaska becomes a territory of the United States

1913.0: New York Governor William Sulzer approves the charter for the Rockefeller Foundation, which begins operations with a $100,000,000 donation from John D. Rockefeller

1913.1: Women's suffrage is enacted in Norway

1913.2: The statue The Little Mermaid in Copenhagen, Denmark, is finished

1913.3: Mohandas Gandhi is arrested while leading a march of Indian miners in South Africa

1914.0: Ford Motor Company announces an eight-hour workday and a daily wage of $5

1914.1: Charlie Chaplin makes his film début in the comedy short Making a Living

1914.2: Gandhi leaves South Africa for the last time, sailing out of Cape Town for England on board the SS Kinfauns Castle

1914.3: The German Empire declares war on the Russian Empire

1915.0: The United States House of Representatives rejects a proposal to give women the right to vote

1915.1: A Fool There Was premières in the United States starring Theda Bara as a femme fatale; she quickly becomes one of early cinema's most sensational stars

1915.2: The U.S. submarine F-4 sinks off Hawaii

1915.3: Charlie Chaplin's film The Tramp released

1916.0: WWI: An attack is planned on Verdun

1916.1: In Munich German automobile company BMW (Die Bayerischen Motoren Werke) is founded

1916.2: J. R. R. Tolkien marries Edith Bratt in England (they will serve as the inspiration for the fictional characters Lúthien and Beren)

1916.3: The Saturday Evening Post publishes its first cover with a Norman Rockwell painting (Boy with Baby Carriage)

1917.0: J. R. R. Tolkien, on medical leave from the British Army, begins writing The Book of Lost Tales (the first version of The Silmarillion), starting with the "Fall of Gondolin"; thus Tolkien's mythopoeic Middle-earth legendarium is first chronicled in prose

1917.1: WWI: President of the United States Woodrow Wilson calls for "peace without victory" in Germany

1917.2: An anti-prostitution drive in San Francisco occurs and police close about 200 prostitution houses

1917.3: The new constitution of Mexico is adopted

1918.0: Finland officially recognized by the Russian SFSR

1918.1: Women's suffrage in the United Kingdom: Representation of the People Act gives most women over 30 the vote

1918.2: Russia switches from the Julian calendar to the Gregorian calendar; the date skips from February 1 to February 14

1918.3: WWI: Finland forms an alliance with Germany

1919.0: Spartacist uprising: Socialist demonstrations in Berlin, Germany turn into an attempted communist revolution

1919.1: Estonian War of Independence: Estonian forces start a general counter-offensive against the Red Army

1919.2: The funeral of Theodore Roosevelt, 26th President of the United States, is held at Christ Church Oyster Bay, Long Island; Roosevelt had died in his sleep at the age of 60, two days earlier

1919.3: Oregon places a one cent per US gallon (0.26¢/liter) tax on gasoline, becoming the first U.S. state to levy a gasoline tax

1920.0: Babe Ruth is traded by the Red Sox for $125,000, the largest sum ever paid for a player at that time

1920.1: The United States Senate refuses to ratify the Treaty of Versailles

1920.2: Adolf Hitler presents his National Socialist Program in Munich to the German Workers' Party (Deutsche Arbeiterpartei) which renames itself as the Nazi Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei)

1920.3: Greece begins using the Gregorian calendar

1921.0: The Allies of World War I reparations commission announce that Germany has to pay 132 billion gold marks ($33 trillion) in annual installments of 2.5 billion

1921.1: The death penalty is abolished in Sweden

1921.2: The first BCG vaccination against tuberculosis is given

1921.3: Adolf Hitler becomes Führer of the Nazi Party

1922.0: The first successful insulin treatment of diabetes is made, by Frederick Banting in Toronto

1922.1: President of the United States Warren G. Harding introduces the first radio in the White House

1922.2: Mohandas Gandhi is arrested in Bombay for sedition

1922.3: In British India, Mahatma Gandhi is sentenced to six years in prison for sedition (he serves only two)

1923.0: Juan de la Cierva invents the autogyro, a rotary-winged aircraft with an unpowered rotor

1923.2: Warner Bros. film studio is formally incorporated in the United States as Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc

1923.3: Louis Armstrong makes his first recording, "Chimes Blues", with King Oliver's Creole Jazz Band

1924.0: Gopinath Saha shoots a man he erroneously thinks is Sir Charles Tegart, the police commissioner of Calcutta, and is arrested soon after

1924.1: The Soviet Union officially declares that Lenin died January 21

1924.2: The United Kingdom recognizes the Soviet Union

1924.3: The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR), based in the U.S. state of New York, is renamed International Business Machines (IBM)

1925.0: Kristiania, the capital of Norway, reverted to its original name of Oslo

1925.1: The Alice Comedy Alice Solves the Puzzle was released by Disney Brothers Cartoon Studio, introducing Bootleg Pete (an early prototype for Pegleg Pete) for the first time

1925.2: The Aristotle University of Thessaloniki in Greece was founded

1925.3: Adolf Hitler published Volume 1 of his personal manifesto Mein Kampf

1926.0: The Berlin International Green Week debuted in Berlin

1926.1: Fox Film bought the patents of the Movietone sound system for recording sound onto film

1927.0: The first transatlantic telephone call is made via radio from New York City to London

1927.1: The first Volvo automobile rolled off the production line in Gothenburg, Sweden

1927.2: Charles Lindbergh makes the first solo, nonstop transatlantic airplane flight, carried out from New York City to Paris, France, in his single-engined aircraft, the Spirit of St. Louis

1927.3: The United Kingdom cuts its diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union due to revelations of espionage and underground agitation

1928.0: Leon Trotsky is exiled to Alma-Ata

1928.1: Charles Lindbergh is presented with the Medal of Honor for his first Transatlantic flight

1928.2: The last section ("wise – wyze") of the original Oxford English Dictionary is completed and published

1928.3: The animated short Plane Crazy is released by Disney Studios in Los Angeles, featuring the first appearances of Mickey and Minnie Mouse

1929.0: Annales d'histoire économique et sociale begins publication in France

1929.1: First appearance of comic strip hero Popeye in Thimble Theatre

1929.2: Vladimir Zworykin takes out the first patent for color television

1930.0: The first diesel engine automobile trip is completed (Indianapolis, Indiana, to New York City) by Clessie Cummins, founder of the Cummins Motor Co

1930.1: The Mickey Mouse comic strip makes its first appearance

1930.2: The Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng launch the Yên Bái mutiny in the hope of ending French colonial rule in Vietnam

1930.3: Mahatma Gandhi informs the British viceroy of India that civil disobedience will begin the following week

1931.0: Albert Einstein begins doing research at the California Institute of Technology, along with astronomer Edwin Hubble

1931.1: Mohandas Gandhi is again released from imprisonment in India

1931.2: Release of the movie City Lights starring Charlie Chaplin

1931.3: The original film version of Dracula with Bela Lugosi is released in the United State

1932.0: The British arrest and intern Mohandas Gandhi and Vallabhbhai Patel

1932.1: Hattie W. Caraway becomes the first woman elected to the United States Senate

1932.2: About 6 million are unemployed in Germany

1932.3: Brave New World, a novel by Aldous Huxley, is first published

1933.0: Nazi leader Adolf Hitler is appointed Chancellor of Germany by President of Germany Paul von Hindenburg

1933.1: Adolf Hitler gives his "Proclamation to the German People" in Berlin

1933.2: In Miami, Giuseppe Zangara attempts to assassinate President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt, but instead fatally wounds the Mayor of Chicago, Anton Cermak

1933.3: The original film version of King Kong, starring Fay Wray, premieres at Radio City Music Hall and the RKO Roxy Theatre in New York City

1934.0: The Japanese company Fuji Photo Film is established

1934.1: In Nazi Germany the political power of the federal states such as Prussia is substantially abolished by the "Law on the Reconstruction of the Reich" (Gesetz über den Neuaufbau des Reiches)

1934.2: Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini meet for the first time, at the Venice Biennale

1934.3: Adolf Hitler becomes Führer of Germany, or head of state combined with that of Chancellor following the death of President Paul von Hindenburg

1935.0: The first canned beer is sold in Richmond, Virginia, United States, by Gottfried Krueger Brewing Company

1935.1: The classic Mickey Mouse cartoon The Band Concert is released by United Artists in the United States

1935.2: In Nazi Germany, Adolf Hitler orders reinstatement of the air force, the Luftwaffe, in violation of the 1919 Treaty of Versailles

1935.3: Adolf Hitler announces German re-armament in violation of the 1919 Treaty of Versailles

1936.0: I Wanna Play House marks the first Warner Bros. cartoon with "target"

1936.1: The first superhero to wear a skin-tight costume and mask, The Phantom, makes his first appearance in U.S. newspapers

2: In violation of the Treaty of Versailles
Nazi Germany reoccupies the Rhineland.[1][2] According to several historians

[3] this is the last time when the Allies could have stopped Hitler with the odds overwhelmingly on their side. Hitler and other Nazis admit that the French army alone could have destroyed the Wehrmacht

1936.3: The longest game in the history of the National Hockey League is played when the Montreal Maroons and Detroit Red Wings go scoreless until 16 and a half minutes into the sixth OT when Mud Bruneteau ends it at 2:25 in the morning

1937.0: The first successful flying car, Waldo Waterman's Aerobile, makes its initial flight

1937.1: The Kamikaze arrives at Croydon Airport in London; it is the first Japanese-built aircraft to fly to Europe

1937.3: The highest recorded temperature in Canada, at Yellow Grass, Saskatchewan, is 45 °C

1938.0: The March of Dimes is established by Franklin Delano Roosevelt

1938.1: Walt Disney's Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, the first cel-animated feature in motion picture history, is released in the United States following a premiere the previous year

1938.2: A nylon bristle toothbrush becomes the first commercial product to be made with nylon yarn

1938.3: The Looney Tunes animated short Porky & Daffy is released

1939.0: Naturwissenschaften publishes evidence that nuclear fission has been achieved by Otto Hahn

1939.1: In Bombay, Mohandas Gandhi begins a fast protesting against British rule in India

1939.2: Students at Harvard University demonstrate the new tradition of swallowing goldfish to reporters

1939.3: Adolf Hitler advises Jozef Tiso to declare Slovakia's independence in order to prevent its partition by Hungary and Poland

1940.0: WWII: Axis powers: Luftwaffe General Hermann Göring assumes control of most war industries in Germany

1940.1: The Three Stooges short subject comedy film You Nazty Spy! released, the first Hollywood parody of Adolf Hitler and the Nazis, with Moe Howard portraying "Moe Hailstone" as the Hitler-parody lead

1940.2: RKO release Walt Disney's second full-length animated film, Pinocchio

1940.3: Tom and Jerry make their debut in Puss Gets the Boot. However it is not until 1941 that their current names are adopted

1941.0: All persons born in Puerto Rico since this day are declared U.S. citizens by birth, through U.S. federal law

1941.1: WWII: The Nazis forcibly restore Pierre Laval to office in occupied Vichy France

1941.2: As the Battle of Moscow begins, temperatures around Moscow drop to -12 °C, and the Soviet Union launches ski troops for the first time against the freezing German forces near the city

1941.3: Attack on Pearl Harbor: Aircraft flying from Imperial Japanese Navy carriers launch a surprise attack on the United States fleet at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii, thus drawing the United States into World War II. The attack begins at 7:48 a.m. Hawaiian Standard Time and is announced on radio stations in the U.S. at about 11:26 p.m. PST (19.26 GMT)

1942.0: WWII: The first American forces arrive in Europe, landing in Northern Ireland

1942.1: WWII: Battle of Stalingrad begins: German troops reach the suburbs of Stalingrad

1942.2: The Holocaust: Anne Frank's family goes into hiding in an attic above her father's office in an Amsterdam warehouse

1942.3: Indian leader, Mohandas Gandhi is arrested in Bombay by British forces

1943.0: Albert Hofmann self-administers the psychedelic drug LSD (which he first synthesized in 1938) for the first time in history, and records the details of his experience

1943.1: WWII: Casablanca Conference: Franklin D. Roosevelt, President of the United States; Winston Churchill, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom; and Generals Charles de Gaulle and Henri Giraud of the Free French forces meet secretly at the Anfa Hotel in Casablanca, Morocco, to plan the Allied European strategy for the next stage of the war

1943.2: Mohandas Gandhi (under arrest by forces of the British Raj in Pune as a member of the Quit India Movement) keeps a hunger strike to protest at his imprisonment

1943.3: Publication in New York of exiled French aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's self-illustrated children's novella The Little Prince, the all-time best-selling book originated in French

1944.0: Winston Churchill and Charles de Gaulle begin a 2-day wartime conference in Marrakech

1944.1: No Exit published by Jean-Paul Sartre

1944.2: WWII: Mohandas Gandhi is released in India

1944.3: WWII: Adolf Hitler survives an assassination attempt led by Claus von Stauffenberg

1945.0: Anne Frank dies of typhus in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, Lower Saxony, Germany

1945.1: President Franklin D. Roosevelt gives what will be his last address to a joint session of the United States Congress, reporting on the Yalta Conference

1945.2: The film Les Enfants du Paradis premières in Paris

1945.3: The Empire of Japan establishes the Empire of Vietnam, a puppet state which will last only until August 23, with Bảo Đại as its ruler

1946.0: Charles de Gaulle resigns as a head of a French provisional government

1946.1: In Philadelphia, General Electric strikers and police clash

1946.2: Vietnam War: Ho Chi Minh signs an agreement with France which recognizes Vietnam as an autonomous state in the Indochinese Federation and the French Union

1946.3: Trial against war criminals begin in Tokyo; the accused include Hideki Tōjō, Shigenori Tōgō and Hiroshi Ōshima

1947.0: Nigeria gains limited autonomy before gaining independence in 1960

1947.2: Christian Dior introduces The "New Look" in women's fashion, in Paris

1947.3: Tom and Jerry cartoon Cat Fishin', is released

1948.0: Warner Brothers shows the first color newsreel (Tournament of Roses Parade and the Rose Bowl)

1948.1: Mahatma Gandhi begins his fast-unto-death in Delhi to stop communal violence during the Partition of India

1948.2: Assassination of Mahatma Gandhi: Indian pacifist and leader Mahatma Gandhi is shot by Nathuram Godse in New Delhi. Also on this day Orville Wright of the pioneering aviators the Wright Brothers dies in Dayton, Ohio

1948.3: Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 is played on television in its entirety for the first time in a series of concerts featuring Arturo Toscanini conducting the NBC Symphony Orchestra in the United States. The chorus is conducted by Robert Shaw

1949.0: Los Angeles receives its first recorded snowfall

1949.1: London Mozart Players perform their first concert at the Wigmore Hall, London

1949.2: English astronomer Fred Hoyle coins the term Big Bang during a BBC Third Programme radio broadcast

1949.3: The Federal Republic of Germany is established

1950.0: Cold War: Klaus Fuchs, German émigré and physicist, confesses to an MI5 interrogator that he is a Soviet spy: For seven years, he passed top secret data on U.S. and British nuclear weapons research to the Soviet Union. Fuchs is formally charged on February 2

1950.1: United States President Harry S. Truman orders the development of the hydrogen bomb, in response to the detonation of the Soviet Union's first atomic bomb in 1949

1950.2: Two Viet Minh battalions attack a French base in French Indochina

1950.3: Albert Einstein warns that nuclear war could lead to mutual destruction

1950.0: Walt Disney releases his 12th animated film, Cinderella in Hollywood

1951.0: United Artists releases sci-fi film The Man from Planet X in the United States

1951.2: The most complete recording of George Gershwin's opera Porgy and Bess up to

1951.3: Walt Disney's 13th animated film, Alice in Wonderland, premieres in London, United Kingdom

1952.0: The University of Tennessee admits its first black student

1952.1: United Kingdom Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that the United Kingdom has an atomic bomb

1952.2: The United States Senate ratifies a peace treaty with Japan

1952.3: Pandit Nehru forms his first government in India

1953.0: Walt Disney's feature film Peter Pan premieres

1953.1: Transsexual Christine Jorgensen returns to New York after successful sex reassignment surgery in Denmark

1953.2: The Pakistan Academy of Sciences is established in Pakistan

1953.3: Ian Fleming publishes his first James Bond novel, Casino Royale, in the United Kingdom

1954.0: French troops begin the battle against the Viet Minh in Dien Bien Phu

1954.1: Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai is released in Japan

1954.2: Vietnam War (run-up): The Battle of Dien Bien Phu ends in a French defeat (the battle began on March 13)

1954.3: Early computer scientist Alan Turing commits suicide

1955.0: Winston Churchill resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom due to ill-health at the age of 80

1955.1: First edition of the Guinness Book of Records is published, in London

1955.2: Alfred Hitchcock Presents debuts on the CBS TV network in the United States

1955.3: The Mickey Mouse Club debuts on the ABC-TV network in the United States

1956.0: Columbia Records first releases Glenn Gould's solo piano recording of Bach's Goldberg Variations

1956.1: Doris Day records her most famous song, "Que Sera, Sera (Whatever Will Be, Will Be)"; it is from Alfred Hitchcock's The Man Who Knew Too Much, in which Day co-stars with James Stewart

1956.2: Elvis Presley releases his first gold album titled Elvis Presley

1956.3: General Electric/Telechron introduces model 7H241 "The Snooz Alarm", first snooze alarm clock ever

1957.0: Wham-O Company produces the first Frisbee

1957.1: United Kingdom colonies Gold Coast and British Togoland become the independent nation of Ghana

1957.2: The French news magazine L'Express reveals that the French army tortures Algerian prisoners

1957.3: 22-year-old Elvis Presley buys Graceland on 3734 Bellevue Boulevard (Highway 51 South) for $US100,000. He and his family move from the house on 1034 Audubon Drive

1958.0: The first Carrefour store opens, in Annecy

1958.1: Anne de Vries releases the fourth and final volume ofJourney Through the Night

1958.2: The first successful American satellite, Explorer 1, is launched into orbit

1958.3: The Amirkabir University of Technology is founded in Tehran

1959.0: The Soviet Union successfully launches the Luna 1 spacecraft from Baikonur Cosmodrome

1959.1: The United States recognizes the new Cuban government of Fidel Castro

1959.2: Charles de Gaulle is inaugurated as the first president of the French Fifth Republic

1959.3: The European Court of Human Rights is established

1960.0: The first televised anime, Three Tales, debuts on NHK

1960.1: In France, President Charles de Gaulle fires Jacques Massu, the commander-in-chief of the French troops in Algeria

1960.2: Elvis Presley returns home from Germany, after being away on military duty for 2 years

1960.3: Alberto Korda takes his iconic photograph of Che Guevara, Guerrillero  Heroico, in Havana

1961.0: In France, a referendum supports Charles de Gaulle's policies on independence for Algeria

1961.1: Supercar, the first family sci-fi TV series filmed in Supermarionation debuts on ATV

1961.2: The Beatles perform for the first time at The Cavern Club

1961.3: United States President John F. Kennedy establishes the Peace Corps

1962.0: The Beatles audition for Decca Records but are rejected

1962.1: The first album on which The Beatles play, My Bonnie, credited to "Tony Sheridan and the Beat Brothers" (recorded last June in Hamburg), is released by Polydor in the U.K

1962.2: Captured American spy pilot Francis Gary Powers is exchanged for captured Soviet spy Rudolf Abel in Berlin

1962.3: Taco Bell fast food restaurant chain is founded by Glen Bell in Downey, California

1962.0: In France, the Évian Accords are adopted in a referendum with a majority of 90%

1963.0: Vietnam War: The Viet Cong win their first major victory in the Battle of Ap Bac

1963.1: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa is exhibited in the United States for the first time, at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C

1963.2: France and West Germany sign the Élysée Treaty

1963.3: French President Charles de Gaulle vetoes the United Kingdom's entry into the European Common Market

1964.0: Introducing... The Beatles is released by Chicago's Vee-Jay Records to get the jump on Capitol Records' release of Meet the Beatles!, scheduled for January 20. The two record companies fight over Vee-Jay's release of this album in court

1964.1: The Beatles vault to the #1 spot on the U.S. singles charts for the first time, with "I Want to Hold Your Hand", starting the British Invasion in America

1964.2: General Nguyễn Khánh leads a bloodless military coup d'état, replacing Dương Văn Minh as Prime Minister of South Vietnam

1965.0: The unmanned Gemini 2 is launched on a suborbital test of various spacecraft systems

1965.1: Vietnam War: Operation Rolling Thunder – The United States Air Force 2d Air Division, United States Navy and Republic of Vietnam Air Force begin a 3½-year aerial bombardment campaign against North Vietnam

1965.2: The film of The Sound of Music premieres at the Rivoli Theater in New York City

1965.3: Gemini 6 and Gemini 7 perform the first controlled rendezvous in Earth orbit

1966.0: The first Acid Test is conducted at the Fillmore, San Jose

1966.1: United States President Lyndon Johnson states that the United States should stay in South Vietnam until Communist aggression there is ended

1966.2: Indira Gandhi is elected Prime Minister of India; she is sworn in January 24

1966.3: Walt Disney dies while producing The Jungle Book, the last animated feature under his personal supervision

1967.0: The Doors release their début album The Doors

1967.1: The Velvet Underground's groundbreaking first album, The Velvet Underground & Nico, is released in the United States. It is initially a commercial failure but receives widespread critical and commercial acclaim in later years

1967.2: In Houston, Texas, boxer Muhammad Ali refuses military service. He is stripped of his boxing title and not allowed to fight for three years

1967.3: Vietnam War: United States General William Westmoreland tells news reporters: "I am absolutely certain that whereas in 1965 the enemy was winning, today he is certainly losing."

1968.0: Việt Cộng soldiers attack the US Embassy, Saigon

1968.1: The Beatles announce the creation of Apple Records in a New York press conference

1968.2: The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty opens for signature

1968.3: Apollo program: NASA launches Apollo 7, the first manned Apollo mission (Wally Schirra, Donn Eisele, Walter Cunningham). Mission goals include the first live television broadcast from orbit and testing the lunar module docking maneuver

1969.0: Led Zeppelin, the first Led Zeppelin album, is released

1969.1: Jim Morrison is arrested in Florida for indecent exposure during a Doors-concert three days earlier

1969.2: Charles de Gaulle steps down as president of France after suffering defeat in a referendum the day before

1969.3: The Woodstock Festival is held in upstate New York, featuring some of the top rock musicians of the era

1970.0: Mick Jagger is fined £200 for possession of cannabis

1970.1: The complete New English Bible is published

1970.2: The Who become the first act to perform rock music (their rock opera, Tommy) at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York

1970.3: American musician Jimi Hendrix dies from an overdose of sleeping pills

1971.0: Evel Knievel sets a world record and jumps 19 cars in Ontario, California

1971.1: Vietnam War: Australia and New Zealand decide to withdraw their troops from Vietnam

1971.2: Greenpeace is founded in Vancouver, Canada

1971.3: Led Zeppelin releases their Fourth Studio album "Led Zeppelin IV", which goes on to sell 23,000,000 copies

1972.0: The California Supreme Court voids the state's death penalty, commuting all death sentences to life in prison

1972.1: The X-rated animated movie Fritz the Cat is released

1972.2: Norwegian EC referendum, 1972: Norway rejects membership in the European Economic Community

1972.3: The first female FBI agents are hired

1973.0: Vietnam War: Citing progress in peace negotiations, U.S. President Richard Nixon announces the suspension of offensive action in North Vietnam

1973.1: Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon, one of rock's landmark albums, is released in the US. It is released in the UK on March 24

1973.2: The World Trade Center officially opens in New York City with a ribbon-cutting ceremony

1973.3: Tu te reconnaîtras by Anne-Marie David (music by Claude Morgan, text by Vline Buggy) wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1973 for Luxembourg

1974.0: Charles de Gaulle Airport opens in Paris, France

1974.1: Stephen King publishes Carrie, his first novel

1974.2: Rubik's Cube puzzle is invented by Hungarian architecture professor Ernő Rubik

1975.0: The United Nations proclaims International Women's Day

1975.1: Vietnam War: North Vietnamese troops attack Ban Mê Thuột, South Vietnam, on their way to capturing Saigon

1975.2: Bobby Fischer refuses to play in a chess match against Anatoly Karpov, giving Karpov the title

1975.3: Monty Python and the Holy Grail is released in theatres

1976.0: Apple Computer Company is formed by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak

1976.1: The punk rock group the Ramones release their first self-titled album

1976.2: The UK and Iceland end the Cod War

1976.3: North Vietnam dissolves the Provisional Government of South Vietnam and unites the two countries to form the Socialist Republic of Vietnam

1977.1: The Centre Georges Pompidou is officially opened by French President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing

1977.2: The Cold War between Cambodia and Vietnam evolves into the Cambodian–Vietnamese War

1977.3: Led Zeppelin sets a new world record attendance for an indoor solo attraction at the Pontiac Silverdome when 76,229 persons attend a concert here on the group's 1977 North American Tour

1978.0: The 1978 FIFA World Cup starts in Argentina

1978.1: Grease, starring John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John is released

1978.2: Garfield, which eventually becomes the world's most widely syndicated comic strip, makes its debu

1979.0: Queen releases "Don't Stop Me Now". It becomes one of their most popular singles

1979.1: Former Sex Pistols bassist Sid Vicious is found dead, aged 21, of a heroin overdose in New York City, the day after being released from a 55-day sentence at Rikers Island prison on bail

1979.3: A nudist beach is established in Brighton

1980.0: Iron Maiden's debut self-titled album Iron Maiden is released

1980.1: Gwangju Uprising: Students in Gwangju, South Korea begin demonstrations, calling for democratic reforms

1980.2: The Empire Strikes Back is released

1980.3: The album Back in Black is released by the Australian band AC/DC

1981.0: The first London Marathon starts with 7,500 runners

1981.1: The first Coca-Cola bottling plant in China is opened

1981.2: Bob Marley dies aged 36 from cancer

1981.3: Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark is released in theaters

1982.0: AT&T Corporation agrees to break up and divest itself of 22 subdivisions

1982.1: Italy beats West Germany 3–1 to win the 1982 FIFA World Cup in Spain

1982.2: In Hong Kong, health warnings on cigarette packets are made statutory

1982.3: The Vietnam Veterans Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C., after a march to its site by thousands of Vietnam War veterans

1983.0: Lotus 1-2-3 is released for IBM PC compatible computers

1983.1: Seatbelt use for drivers and front seat passengers becomes mandatory in the United Kingdom

1984.0: Apple Computer places the Macintosh personal computer on sale in the United States

1984.1: Astronauts Bruce McCandless II and Robert L. Stewart make the first untethered space walk

1984.2: Marvin Gaye is shot to death by his father, one day before his 45th birthday

1984.3: Elton John plays the famous Night and Day Concert at Wembley Stadium

1985.0: The Internet's Domain Name System is created

1985.1: The Economic Cooperation Organization (ECO) is formed

1985.2: In Hollywood, the charity single "We Are the World" is recorded by USA for Africa

1986.0: The first PC virus, Brain, starts to spread

1986.1: Pixar Animation Studios are opened in California

1986.2: Nintendo releases the first game in the Zelda series, The Legend of Zelda, in Japan on the Famicom

1986.3: Microsoft Corporation holds its initial public offering of stock shares

1987.0: The Irish rock band U2 releases their studio album The Joshua Tree

1987.1: The Simpsons cartoon first appears as a series of shorts on The Tracey Ullman Show

1987.2: The first ever Rugby World Cup kicks off with New Zealand playing Italy at Eden Park, Auckland

1987.3: Edwards v. Aguillard: The Supreme Court of the United States rules that a Louisiana law requiring that creation science be taught in public schools whenever evolution is taught is unconstitutiona

1988.0: The Phantom of the Opera, the longest running Broadway play ever, opens

1: The first McDonald's restaurant in a country run by a Communist party opens in Belgrade
Yugoslavia.[7] In 1989 it will be followed by one in Budapest
and in 1990 in Moscow and Shenzhen

1988.2: The Last Emperor (directed by Bernardo Bertolucci) wins nine Oscars

1988.3: TAT-8, the first transatlantic telephone cable to use optical fibers, is completed. This led to more robust connections between the American and European Internet.

1989.0: Tim Berners-Lee produces the proposal document that will become the blueprint for the World Wide Web

1989.1: Transhumanism – Genetic modification of adult human beings is tried for the first time, a gene tagging trial

1989.2: The world's first HDTV broadcasts commence in Japan, in analog

1989.3: The last two Japanese World War II holdout troops surrender

1990.0: Globalization – The first McDonald's in Moscow, Russia opens 8 months after construction began on 3 May 1989. 8 months later the first McDonald's in Mainland China is opened in Shenzhen

1990.1: Smoking is banned on all cross-country flights in the United States

1990.2: The Ultimate Warrior defeats Hulk Hogan to win the WWF Championship in a Title for Title, winner takes all match at WrestleMania VI in front of nearly 68,000 people at the SkyDome in Toronto, Ontario

1991.0: Street Fighter II released for arcades

1991.1: Comedy Central is launched on cable television in its current format

1991.2: The Super Nintendo Entertainment System (or "Super Nintendo") is released in the United States

1991.3: China–Vietnam relations: China and Vietnam restore diplomatic relations after a 13-year rift which followed the 1979 Sino-Vietnamese War

1992.0: President of the United States George H. W. Bush meets with President of Russia Boris Yeltsin at Camp David, where they formally declare that the Cold War is over

1992.1: Dow Corning announces that it will stop manufacturing silicone breast implants

1992.2: Barney & Friends makes its debut on PBS

1992.3: Sweden wins the Ice Hockey World Championships in Prague

1993.0: IBM announces a $4.97 billion loss for 1992, the largest single-year corporate loss in United States history to date

1993.1: Super Mario Bros., the first major American movie based on a video game, is released in theaters

1993.2: PLO leader Yasir Arafat and Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin, with US President, Bill Clinton

1993.3: id Software releases Doom, a seminal first-person shooter that uses advanced 3D graphics for computer games

1994.0: Record cold temperatures hit the eastern United States. The coldest temperature ever measured in Indiana state history, −36 °F (−38 °C), is recorded in New Whiteland, Indiana

1994.1: Kurt Cobain, songwriter and frontman for the band Nirvana, is found dead at his Lake Washington home, apparently of a single self-inflicted gunshot wound

1994.2: Hacker Kevin Poulsen pleads guilty to 7 counts of mail fraud, wire and computer fraud, money laundering, and obstruction of justice

1994.3: The Lion King, the highest grossing hand-drawn animated feature, is released by Walt Disney Pictures

1994.0: Microsoft announces it will no longer sell or support the MS-DOS operating system separately from Microsoft Windows. This had been its mainstay since 1980

1995.1: Norwegian rocket incident: A rocket launched from the space exploration centre at Andøya, Norway is briefly interpreted by the Russians as an incoming attack

1995.2: Hacker Kevin Mitnick is arrested by the FBI and charged with penetrating some of the United States' most "secure" computer systems

1995.3: Jacques Chirac is elected president of France

1996.0: Motorola introduces the Motorola StarTAC Wearable Cellular Telephone, the world's smallest and lightest mobile phone to date

1996.1: Chess computer "Deep Blue" defeats world chess champion Garry Kasparov for the first time

1996.2: Pokémon Red and Blue are released in Japan by Nintendo as Pocket Monsters: Red and Green, the first role-playing video game in the Pokémon series, developed by Game Freak

1996.3: Canadian singer Alanis Morissette wins the top honor, Album of the Year award, at the 38th Annual Grammy Awards. At age 21, she is the youngest person to ever win this award, a record she will hold until 2010, when Taylor Swift wins

1996.4: The Nintendo 64 video game system is released in Japan

1996.5: The General Motors EV1, the first production electric car of the modern era, is launched and becomes available for lease

1997.0: Final Fantasy VII, one of the most popular video games of all time, is released in Japan

1997.2: IBM's Deep Blue defeats Garry Kasparov in the last game of the rematch, the first time a computer beats a chess World champion in a match

1997.3: Digital Equipment Corporation files antitrust charges against chipmaker Intel

1997.4: Microsoft buys a $150 million share of financially troubled Apple Computer

1997.5: Be Here Now, the third album from English rock band Oasis, becomes the fastest selling album in UK history

1998.0: First Computer-assisted Bone Segment Navigation, performed at the University of Regensburg, Germany

1998.1: Netscape released Mozilla source code under an open source license. This is described in The Book of Mozilla, 3:31

1998.3: J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is published

1998.4: France beats Brazil 3–0 in the football World Cup final

1998.5: Biologists report in the journal Science how they sequenced the genome of the bacterium that causes syphilis, Treponema pallidum

1999.2: Bill Gates' personal fortune makes him the wealthiest individual in the world due to the increased value of Microsoft stock

1999.3: SpongeBob SquarePants debuts on Nickelodeon. It becomes the longest running animated children's TV show on channel to date

1999.4: Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace is released in theaters. It becomes the highest grossing Star Wars film until The Force Awakens 16 years later

1999.5: Apple Computer releases the Power Macintosh G4

2000.0: United States v. Microsoft Corp.: Microsoft is ruled to have violated United States antitrust laws by keeping "an oppressive thumb" on its competitors

2000.1: 405 The Movie, the first short film widely distributed on the Internet, is released

2000.3: Steve Jobs introduces the public beta of Mac OS X for US$29.95

2000.4: The 2000 Summer Olympics close in Sydney, Australia

2001.0: The world's first self-contained artificial heart is implanted in Robert Tools

2001.1: Windows XP is launched by Microsoft

2001.2: The iPod is first introduced by Apple

2002.0: Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl is kidnapped in Pakistan, accused of being a CIA agent by his captors

2002.1: In Moscow, United States President George W. Bush and Russian President Vladimir Putin sign the Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty to replace the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 and the START II Treaty of 1993

2002.2: The United Nations World Summit on Sustainable Development, successor of the Conference on the Human Environment, World Commission on Environment and Development, and the Conference on Environment and Development, opens

2003.0: Prometea, the first horse cloned by Italian scientists, is born

2003.1: Perihelic opposition: Mars makes its closest approach to Earth in over 50,000 years

2003.2: Smart 1, a European Space Agency satellite, is launched from French Guiana

2003.3: With its ruling in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court makes the state the first in the United States to legalize same-sex marriage

2004.3: The Ubuntu operating system is first released

2005.0: YouTube, the most popular video sharing website, is founded

2005.1: Peace Mission 2005, the first joint China–Russia military exercise, begins its 8-day training on the Shandong Peninsula

2005.2: The 2005 French riots begin after 2 young immigrants die in Clichy-sous-Bois, while hiding from the police

2005.3: Surgeons in France carry out the first human face transplant

2006.0: The Human Genome Project publishes the last chromosome sequence, in Nature

2006.1: Former Beatle Paul McCartney turns 64 after writing "When I'm Sixty-Four" at age 16

2006.3: The Chinese River Dolphin or Baiji becomes extinct

2007.0: Apple Inc.'s CEO and founder, Steve Jobs, announces the first generation iPhone (it goes on sale in the United States on June 29)

2007.1: French high speed passenger train, the TGV, reaches a top speed of 574.8 km/h (357.2 mph), breaking the record for the world's fastest conventional train

2007.2: A 2,100-year-old melon is discovered by archaeologists in western Japan

2007.3: Mauritania was the last country to criminalize slavery in 2007 (officially "abolished" in 1981), making the practice illegal everywhere in the world

2008.0: The price of petroleum hits $100 per barrel for the first time

2008.1: Fidel Castro announces his resignation as President of Cuba, effective February 24

2008.2: Íngrid Betancourt and 14 other hostages are rescued from FARC by Colombian security forces

2008.3: Summer Olympics take place in Beijing, China

2009.0: A Russian and an American satellite collide over Siberia, creating a large amount of space debris

2009.1: North Korean leader Kim Jong-il pardons two American journalists, who had been arrested and imprisoned for illegal entry earlier in the year, after former U.S. President Bill Clinton meets with Kim in North Korea

2009.2: At the G-20 Pittsburgh summit, world leaders announce that the G-20 will assume greater leverage over the world economy, replacing the role of the G8, in an effort to prevent another financial crisis like that in 2008

2009.3: Astronomers discover GJ 1214 b, the first-known exoplanet on which water could exist

2010.0: The sculpture L'Homme qui marche I by Alberto Giacometti sells in London for £65 million (US$103.7 million), setting a new world record for a work of art sold at auction

2010.1: The eurozone and the International Monetary Fund agree to a €110 billion bailout package for Greece. The package involves sharp Greek austerity measures

2010.2: Scientists conducting the Neanderthal genome project announce that they have sequenced enough of the Neanderthal genome to suggest that Neanderthals and humans may have interbred

2010.3: Eurozone countries agree to a rescue package for the Republic of Ireland from the European Financial Stability Facility in response to the country's financial crisis

2011.0: An estimated two billion people watch the wedding of Prince William, Duke of Cambridge and Catherine Middleton at Westminster Abbey in London

2011.1: President Barack Obama announces that Osama bin Laden, the founder and leader of the militant group Al-Qaeda, was killed on May 2, 2011 during an American military operation in Pakistan

2011.2: The European Union agrees to a €78 billion rescue deal for Portugal. The bailout loan will be equally split between the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism, the European Financial Stability Facility, and the International Monetary Fund

2011.3: The Mars Science Laboratory rover Curiosity, the most elaborate Martian exploration vehicle to date, is launched from the Kennedy Space Center. It lands on Mars on August 6, 2012

2012.0: Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3, a North Korean Earth observation satellite, explodes shortly after launch. The United States and other countries had called the impending launch a violation of United Nations Security Council demands. The launch was planned to mark the centenary of the birth of Kim Il-sung, the founder of the republic.

2012.1: A pastel version of The Scream, by the Norwegian painter Edvard Munch, sells for US$120 million in a New York City auction, setting a new world record for an auctioned work of art

2012.2: Curiosity, the Mars Science Laboratory mission's rover, successfully lands on Mars

2012.3: In Qatar, the UN Climate Change Conference agrees to extend the Kyoto Protocol until 2020

2013.0: North Korea conducts its third underground nuclear test, prompting widespread condemnation and tightened economic sanctions from the international community

2013.1: American scientists use a 3D printer to create a living lab-grown ear from collagen and animal ear cell cultures. In the future, it is hoped, similar ears could be grown to order as transplants for human patients suffering from ear trauma or amputation

2013.2: Three Studies of Lucian Freud, a series of portraits of Lucian Freud by the British painter Francis Bacon, sells for US$142.4 million in a New York City auction, setting a new world record for an auctioned work of art

2013.3: In a study published in the scientific journal Nature, researchers from Oregon Health & Science University in the United States describe the first creation of human embryonic stem cells by cloning

2014.0: Belgium becomes the first country in the world to legalise euthanasia for terminally ill patients of any age

2014.1: FIFA World Cup is held in Brazil, and is won by Germany

2014.2: U.S. President Barack Obama announces the resumption of normal relations between the U.S. and Cuba

2015.0: The Swiss National Bank abandons the cap on the franc's value relative to the euro, causing turmoil in international financial markets

2015.1: Version O of Les Femmes d'Alger by Pablo Picasso sells for US$179.3 million at Christie's auction in New York, while the sculpture L'Homme au doigt by Alberto Giacometti sells for US$141.3 million, setting a new world record for a painting and for a sculpture, respectively

2015.2: Ireland votes to legalize same-sex marriage, becoming the first country to legalize same-sex marriage by popular vote

2015.3: Scientists announce the discovery of Homo naledi, a previously unknown species of early human in South Africa

2016.0: Summer Olympics will be held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
